questiontext.text: Is 26978244 a globally unique identifier for the PubMed article on the FAIR principles?

feedback.text: Sorry. 26978244 is unique within PubMed but is not globally unique.

questiontext.text: What should be used to name (identify) things as per the linked data principles?
An RDF triple comprises a subject, predicate and object. Which of the following would be a proper predicate?

feedback.text: A name is a potential subject and/or object
A size can be a potential subject and/or object

questiontext.text: What are some of the FAIR principles?

feedback.text: F in FAIR stands for findable

questiontext.text: The benefits of using Linked Open Data include

answer.text: Requires all data to be stored together

feedback.text: Data does not need to be stored together

answer.text: Facilitates data interchange on the web
Allows for data integration across sources

questiontext.text: The object of the triple for the following statement: Purkinje Cells are located in the Cerebellum

feedback.text: Purkinje Cell is the subject in the triple
Cerebellum is the object in the triple

questiontext.text: Are the specifications for FAIR a standard?

feedback.text: Sorry. The FAIR principles are not a standard. Each community must develop their own standards that support the principles outlined by FAIR.

questiontext.text: If data are made FAIR they are openly available

feedback.text: Sorry. The FAIR principles do not require data to be openly available.

questiontext.text: What are the benefits of using BIDS?

answer.text: It will be easy for another researcher to work on your data
There are a growing number of data analysis software packages that can understand data organised according to BIDS
Databases such as OpenNeuro.org accept datasets organised according to BIDS
Validation tools can check your dataset integrity

questiontext.text: In the BIDS specification a Session can denote

answer.text: A logical grouping of neuroimaging and behavioral data consistent across subjects
A visit in a longitudinal study
A continuous uninterrupted block of time during which a brain scanning instrument was acquiring data

feedback.text: Sorry, this is a data acquisition.

answer.text: A set of neuroimaging and behavioral data acquired for a purpose of a particular study

questiontext.text: Does a BIDS dataset require a dataset description file?

feedback.text: Sorry, every dataset MUST include this file.

questiontext.text: According to the BIDS specification which of the following would a correct name for a subject's fMRI filename for a task completed during a second visit?

feedback.text: Sorry, this doesn't include a subject label
Sorry, this doesn't include a task entity.
Sorry, this doesn't include a session entity.

questiontext.text: The Neuroimaging Data Model (NIDM) captures brain data, workflow, and results in a structured format utilizing

answer.text: a data model based on provenance
a data model based on RDF triples
a data model based on CSV tabular files

feedback.text: Sorry, NIDM is a semantic web based standard

answer.text: a data model based on workflows

feedback.text: Sorry, NIDM can represent workflows, however, the model is based on the W3C provenance standard

questiontext.text: Best practices for Neuroimaging can be found in which recommendation
What are some best practices for publishing data

answer.text: adequate funds for proper management and curation of the data
data management at the end of the research lifecycle

feedback.text: Sorry, you should practice proper data management throughout the research lifecycle

answer.text: ensure you have the proper permissions to make your data open from your institution

questiontext.text: Are there formal guidelines for citing published data

feedback.text: Sorry, these guidelines are found in the Joint Declaration of Data Citation principles.
